landing.title: Preacher Helper, built for preachers
landing.subtitle: Capture voice and notes, let AI organize outlines, and keep every scripture reference aligned before you preach.
landing.secondaryHint: Loads safe demo data ‚Äî no signup needed
landing.valueCapture: Capture ideas in seconds with voice-to-text and quick notes.
landing.valueStructure: AI keeps your outline coherent, balanced, and editable.
landing.valueDeliver: Keep scripture, tags, and thoughts in one focused workspace.
landing.heroHighlightSubtitle: A focused flow for capturing, shaping, and delivering
landing.featuresTitle: What you get out of the box
landing.workflowTitle: Go from spark to sermon without losing focus
landing.workflowCaptureDescription: Record voice or type notes instantly while scripture references stay attached.
landing.workflowShapeDescription: Use AI structuring to balance intro, main idea, and conclusion without losing your tone.
landing.workflowDeliverDescription: Export, share, or keep everything in the dashboard so you are ready when you step up.
landing.bottomCtaSubtitle: Open the workspace and keep every idea moving forward.

featureCards.recordingDescription: Voice-to-text with automatic saves so every spark stays.
featureCards.structuringDescription: Turn scattered thoughts into balanced outlines with guardrails.
featureCards.analysisDescription: Keep references, tags, and gaps visible while you write.
featureCards.handOffDescription: Share, export, or continue editing without losing your structure.

introductionInfo.title: Introduction goals:
introductionInfo.prayer: Call to prayer so the seed is sown and received with faith

outlineHelp.title: Quick guide for point

outlineHelp.argumentation: Argumentation: why to believe this ‚Äî context, cross‚Äëreferences, sound reasoning.
outlineHelp.application: Application: what to do and how ‚Äî a concrete step tied to the author‚Äôs intent.

actions.selectPassage: Select the passage and define its boundaries

passageSummary.title: Capture the gist
passageSummary.label: In your own words: what is this passage about?
passageSummary.placeholder: Write a brief 1‚Äì2 sentence summary to keep the main idea in view‚Ä¶

confirmation.readWholeBookOnce: I have read the whole book once

exegeticalPlan.title: Exegetical Plan
exegeticalPlan.intro: An exegetical plan helps see the overall flow of what the text says.

simpleStudy.title: Simple study of the text structure
simpleStudy.note: This section explains how to compose the exegetical plan.
simpleStudy.definition: A passage plan is a structural expression of the development of its main idea. It must arise from the text, not be imposed on it.
simpleStudy.requirementsIntro: Each point of the plan should meet several requirements:
simpleStudy.req1: First, it must come from the text.
simpleStudy.req2: Second, it should reveal the main idea of the passage.
simpleStudy.req3: Third, it should be parallel with other points.
simpleStudy.req4: Fourth, it should be short, concise and precise.
simpleStudy.goal: The goal is not to build a perfect construction, but to reflect the development of the main idea of the passage.

exegeticalPlan.exampleHint: Write your example or expand the plan based on your text.

example.title: Example 1 Peter
example.topic: On the submission of wives to husbands (3:1‚Äì6)
example.notEvidenceTitle: 1) What does not testify to submission

authorIntent.title: Author's intent
authorIntent.description: The original meaning the author put in when writing these verses
authorIntent.placeholder: Describe the author's intent for this passage...

blockDiagram.title: Block diagram
blockDiagram.description: From the block diagram, we will compose the exegetical plan
blockDiagram.notAvailableYet: This feature is currently under development and will be available in a future update. The block diagram will provide a visual representation of the text structure to help compose the exegetical plan.

builder.title: Exegetical Plan Builder
builder.empty: No points yet. Start by adding a main point.

note.title: Note
note.text: The main idea of the text should align with the main idea of the context.

contextIdea.title: Context main idea
contextIdea.instruction: Write what the context is about
contextIdea.placeholder: Write what the context is about...

textIdea.title: Text main idea
textIdea.instruction1: Formulate the whole text into one sentence
textIdea.instruction2: After formulating the main idea, read the passage again through the lens of your main idea to verify you identified it correctly
textIdea.placeholder: Formulate the whole text into one sentence...

argumentation.title: Argumentation from the text
argumentation.instruction: Identify argumentation that supports the main idea (from the text)
argumentation.placeholder: Identify argumentation that supports the main idea...

tt.definition1: Identify how the passage relates to an absolute, universal truth.
tt.definition2: God‚Äôs principles are unchanging and true for all people, all times, all places.
tt.question: What TIMELESS BIBLICAL TRUTH do I want to convey?
tt.otNt: If preaching from the OT, find the same truth in the NT as well.
tt.warning1: Do not invent or import a universal truth ‚Äî derive it from context and reliable historical-cultural data.

howToFind.title: How to find TBT?
howToFind.scan: Read the passage and identify the key verse(s) around which the whole text revolves.
howToFind.fromKeyVerse: From the key verse, derive the universal truth.

examplePhilip.title: Example: Philip and the Eunuch (Acts 8)
examplePhilip.key: Key: Acts 8:36‚Äì37 ‚Äî faith as the condition for baptism.
examplePhilip.explains: This key explains the whole text:
examplePhilip.q1: Why did the angel send Philip?
examplePhilip.q2: What hindered the eunuch? Not his condition but lack of faith.
examplePhilip.q4: Why did the eunuch go away rejoicing? He became part of the church.

example2Peter.title: Example: 2 Pet. 1:2‚Äì11
example2Peter.summary: Believers are granted all they need; therefore show your faith, entering the Kingdom.
example2Peter.key: Key: 2 Pet. 1:5 ‚Äî ‚Äòmake every effort, add to your faith‚Ä¶‚Äô.
example2Peter.q3: What is the result of such faith?

cc.road: From every verse there is a road to Christ ‚Äî seek it, don‚Äôt force it.

goal.purpose: The main idea becomes the goal to which your exposition is devoted.
goal.keepSearching: Keep searching until you find it ‚Äî with practice, author‚Äôs intent indicators become clearer.
goal.typeProclamation: Proclamation: declare God‚Äôs will as a herald.
goal.typeExhortative: Exhortative: move listeners to purposeful action.

timelessTruth.title: Timeless Biblical Truth
timelessTruth.instruction: Identify a universal truth from the text (true for all people, all times) based on context and sound evidence.

christConnection.title: Connection to Christ
christConnection.instruction: Consider how the main idea leads to Christ. Seek the road to Christ from the text without forcing it.
christConnection.placeholder: Describe the text‚Äôs connection to Christ...
christConnection.warning: Be careful: if you don‚Äôt see a connection, don‚Äôt force it.

goal.title: What goal am I leading to?
goal.placeholder: Write the goal in one clear sentence...
goal.note: Often the goal is tied to the passage‚Äôs main verb. Write it as a full sentence ‚Äî it becomes the focus of your explanation.

note.usingTBT: With the Timeless Biblical Truth, form your thesis
note.mainMessage: This is the main message to convey
note.naming: Main idea is also called theme, big idea, thesis
note.verb: Often tied to the passage‚Äôs main verb (not always)

exegetical.title: Exegetical Thesis
exegetical.definition: A concise, accurate expression of the text‚Äôs main idea from careful study
exegetical.whereFound: Sometimes explicit; sometimes from repeated ideas or context analysis

homiletical.title: Homiletical Thesis & Questions

q.why: Why should I preach this truth to my church?
q.impact: How will this truth foster spiritual maturity in my church?
q.practical: Which practical questions of my audience does it answer and how?
q.practicalPh: List practical questions and how it answers them...

homiletical.own: State the homiletical thesis in your own words

oneSentence.title: Thesis in one sentence (‚â§ 20 words)
oneSentence.question: Usually tied to the main points via a question word: why, how, what, when, where
oneSentence.pluralKey: Use a plural key noun that unites the points
oneSentence.transition: A transition sentence connects thesis to points; key component ‚Äî the key noun
oneSentence.sermon: Entire sermon compressed into one sentence
oneSentence.transitionPh: Bridge thesis to the main points...
oneSentence.sermonPh: Essence of the sermon in one line...

homiletic.note: Take the exegetical structure and make it presentable for listeners ‚Äî accessible and clear.

modernTranslation.p1: Write a modern-language translation of the selected passage.
modernTranslation.p2: Compare how it‚Äôs phrased in modern Bible translations.
modernTranslation.p3: Ensure the modern rendering matches the correct meaning without additions or omissions.

updatedPlan.p1: Based on the modern rendering, compose a new ‚Äòactualized‚Äô plan.
updatedPlan.p2: Sometimes the exegetical and the ‚Äòactualized‚Äô plan fully coincide.

sermonPlan.definition: After defining the thesis, identify how the author proves and develops the idea.
sermonPlan.unity: Strive for unity, order, and progress; keep logical sequencing.
sermonPlan.transitions: Provide clear transitions between parts of the sermon.
sermonPlan.principles: Each (sub)point supports the thesis; one assertion per point; prove and illustrate from Scripture; show application.

planDefinition.title: Defining the passage plan
planDefinition.p1: After you form the thesis of the passage, consider how the author supports and proves the idea.

diagram.title: The plan is closely tied to the text diagram:
diagram.basedOnStructure: It is based on the text‚Äôs structure (exegetical plan).
diagram.topicSentences: Find the key sentences in each exegetical point (topic sentences).
diagram.intentRelation: Relate each topic sentence to the author‚Äôs intent.
diagram.commonAcrossPoints: Identify what unites all points of the exegetical plan.

unityOrderProgress.title: Unity, order, and progress
unityOrderProgress.logicalChronological: Points should have logical and chronological connection:

principles.title: General principles for composing a sermon plan
principles.p1: Each point must support the sermon thesis.
principles.p2: Each subpoint must support the main point it belongs to.
principles.p3: Each (sub)point should consist of one assertion.
principles.p4: Each (sub)point should accomplish the goal set by the thesis.
principles.p5: Each group of points should be united by one idea.
principles.p6: Each group of points should have a parallel structure.
principles.p7: You cannot have a single subpoint: if there is 1 ‚Äî there must be 2; if A ‚Äî then B.
principles.p8: Each point must be expressed clearly.
principles.p9: Each point must be proven or supported from Scripture and sound logic.
principles.p10: Each point should be illustrated or explained; help listeners apply the truth in practice.

items.i4: Meeting the Apostles and confirming the Gospel (1:18‚Äì19; 2:1‚Äì2)
Witness of Christ to the ends of the earth

qualities.title: c) Different qualities of one subject

items.deductive: 1) Deductive: thesis/title stated at the beginning; the sermon substantiates the thesis.
items.inductive: 2) Inductive: thesis or title is formed at the end of the study.
items.narrative: 3) Narrative: from a historical narrative text derive biblical principles and commands.
items.biographical: 4) Biographical: study a biblical character‚Äôs life (stage) and draw lessons.
items.problemSolution: 5) Problem ‚Üí Solution: raise a relevant problem from the text and give a biblical solution.
items.thematic: 6) Thematic: reveal an important topic using several Scripture texts.
items.motivational: 7) Motivational: goal is to move listeners to important church decisions.
items.dramatic: 8) Dramatic: preacher‚Äôs monologue to involve listeners emotionally and spiritually.

modernTranslation.placeholder: Write your modern translation of the passage...
